summary.seg: This manuscript is a late 13th- or early 14th-century copy of homilies on moral subjects. The text is ascribed to the Father of Church John Chrysostom in the manuscript, but it is now attributed to an otherwise unknown Symeon monachus (perhaps 11th century). The editor of the homilies, Paisios Hieromonachos, Κατάνυξις. Σύγγραμμα ἱερὸν συντεθὲν ὑπὸ τοῦ ὁσίου καὶ θεοφόρου πατρὸς ἡμῶν Συμεὼν τοῦ Μεταφραστοῦ (Athens: Nicolas Rousopoulos, 1873), while attributing them to Symeon the Metaphrast, also notes that the manuscripts are uncertain about their attribution. J. Darrouzès, 'Bulletin critique' in Revue des études byzantines, 9 (1951), p. 172-191 , at p. 176 (with reference to Vatican City, Bibliotheca Apostolica Vaticana, Vaticanus gr. 715) states that the author of the homilies can be identified neither with Symeon the New Theologian (949-1022) nor with Symeon the Metaphrast. (cf. S.J. Voicu, 'Fonti patristiche di Simeone monaco', in Rivista di studi bizantini e neoellenici, n.s. 27 (1990), p. 191-94).
The provenance of the manuscript is unknown. It could have belonged to Richard Porson (1759-1808), Regius Professor of Greek from 1792, before it came to the Wren Library.
The manuscript was rebound Nov. 2020-Jan. 2021; the new endleaves (ff. [i-iv] and [xi-xiv]) and the new binding have not been photographed.

msItem.author: Symeon monachus
msItem.title: Thesaurus sive Sermones de passionibus, virtutibus et vitiis (Sermones 1-17 ed. Paisios)
msItem.rubric: f. 1r Τοῦ ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν Ἰωάννου ἀρχιεπισκόπου Κωνσταντινουπόλεως Χρυσοστόμου περὶ τοῦ δεῖν πάντα τῶν οἰκείων ἁμαρτιῶν ἐξομολόγησιν ποιεῖσθαι καὶ διὰ παντὸς πρὸ ὀφθαλμῶν ἔχειν τὸν θάνατον
msItem.incipit: f. 1r Ἀγαθὸν τὸ ἐξομολογεῖσθαι τῶ κυρίω φησὶν ὁ προφήτης· καὶ γὰρ ἀληθῶς ἀγαθὸν καὶ καλὸν ἐξομολογήσις
msItem.explicit: f. 84v ἀμαρτάνουσιν εἰ οὖν ἡμῖν τοῖς πονηροῖς
msItem.note: Ascribed in the manuscript to John Chrysostom John Chrysostom

list.item: Hom. 3: ff. 11r-16v Περὶ γλώσσης καὶ καταλαλιᾶς (p. 23-35)
Hom. 4: ff. 17r-20v Περὶ φθόνου καὶ μισαδελφίας (p. 36-44)
Hom. 5: ff. 20v-22v Περὶ ἀγάπης καὶ περὶ τοῦ μὴ ὀργίζεσθαι (p. 44-49)
Hom. 7: ff. 25v-33r Περὶ ἁγνείας καὶ σωφροσύνης (p. 58-69)
Hom. 8: ff. 33r-44v Περὶ ἁγνείας καὶ σωφροσύνης καὶ περὶ τοῦ ἀπέχεσθαι πορνείας (p. 69-91)
Hom. 10: ff. 48v-50v Περὶ νηστείας καὶ γαστριμαργίας καὶ τοῦ μηδ' ὅλως γογγίζειν (p. 101-105)
Hom. 12: ff. 53r-60v Περὶ τοῦ μὴ θαρρεῖν ἐν πίστει μόνη ἄνευ ἀγαθῶν ἔργων (p. 110-127)
Hom. 14: ff. 64v-68v Περὶ ἐλεημοσύνης καὶ εὐσπλαγχίας (p. 136-144)
Hom. 17: ff. 79r-84v Περὶ ἀσκήσεως καὶ ἀποταγῆςβίου (p. 170-185 l. 26)

support.material: ff. ff. 1r-84v, paper, folded in octavo, not watermarked.

supportDesc.foliation: [i-vii] + 1-84 + [viii-xiv]. Modern foliation in pencil in Arabic numerals, recto, upper right corner.

collation.p:
Although the binding of the volume too tight to determine the collation from material evidence, a possible structure of the leaves may be inferred from the position of the sewing threads between ff. 4v and 5r, 30v and 31r, 42v and 43r, 53v and 54r, 66v and 67r, 77v and 78r, as follows:
Quires 1-28 ff. 1r-16v
Quire 38+1 ff. 17r-25v
Quire 410 ff. 26r-35v
Quire 514-1 ff. 36r-48v
Quire 610 ff. 49r-58v
Quire 716 ff. 59r-58v
Quire 86 ff. 75r-80v
Quire 98-4 ff. 81r-84v
collation.signatures: An incomplete series of signatures in Arabic numerals, written in pencil, and not corresponding to the collation above, is present on ff. 17r (3), 25r (4) 36r (5) 57r (8) 65r (9) 81r (11), in all likelihood inserted by M.R. James.

condition.p: The paper leaves have a soft, felty texture. The textblock has suffered from worm damage and there are some detached leaves, repaired in 2020-2021.

layoutDesc.layout:
ff. 1r-84r: written space 160 105
36 lines per page.

handNote.p: The manuscript is written in a mixed minuscule script, upright or slanting slightly to the right, in black ink. The writing is characterized by large lunate epsilon and kappa and the epsilon-pi ligature in which pi is performed in the form of a large sampi.
Syllabic abbreviations are rare, and mute iota is absent. Punctuation includes the middle and upper point and full stop.

decoDesc.decoNote: A faded headpiece in red ink on f. 1r, single decorated lines (e.g. f. 8v) or cord motif (e.g. f. 17r) at the beginning of each homily.
Coloured initials in faded red ink.

additions.p: Notes by a reader with reference to the Bible quotations in the text, a few lines on the margins (f. 10v), and running titles.
A note in pencil on former left cover, inner: This down as belonging to Porson in Class Book.

binding.p: The manuscript was rebound Nov. 2020-Jan. 2021; the former binding from the 18th century is preserved in a box along with some remains of the headband and parchment strips.

The 18th-century binding is made of boards covered with full tanned calfskin tightback, edges are tooled in gold. The spine is in light brown skin, the title is tooled in gold on a label in brown leather. A parchment guard was present before the first leaf and after the last leaf. Remains of the headband and parchment strips are enclosed in melinex.
The 21st-century binding has not been imaged. It is made of a brown flax-covered paper, covered with limp vellum. Endleaves are constructed of two bifolia of handmade paper (not imaged).

history.origin: The manuscript was copied in the late 13th or early 14th century.
history.provenance: According to a note on the former left cover, inner, probably added by the Sub-Librarian William White, the manuscript belonged to Porson, Richard, 1759-1808 Richard Porson (1759-1808) , Fellow of Trinity College and Regius Professor of Greek.
history.acquisition: If the manuscript belonged to R. Porson, it could have entered into the Wren Library after his death, in 1808.

recordHist.source: Description (2020) draws on M.R. James, The Western Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge, vol. 1, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1900, p. 236-237.

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.

monogr.title: The western manuscripts in the library of Trinity College: a descriptive catalogue
Codices Chrysostomici Graeci I Codices Britanniae et Hiberniae
